column2: What difference is there between a bottle and a flagon.
column3: What difference is there between a bottle and a flagon.

column2: Great difference; for the bottle is stopped and shut up with a stopple, but the flagon with a vice (La bouteille est fermee a bouchon, et le flaccon a vis.).
column3: Great difference; for the bottle is stopped and shut up with a stopple, but the flagon with a vice (La bouteille est fermee a bouchon, et le flaccon a vis.).

column2: Bravely and well played upon the words!
column3: Bravely and well played upon the words!

column2: Our fathers drank lustily, and emptied their cans.
column3: Our fathers drank lustily, and emptied their cans.

column2: Well cacked, well sung!
column3: Well cacked, well sung!

column2: Come, let us drink: will you send nothing to the river?
column3: Come, let us drink: will you send nothing to the river?

column2: Here is one going to wash the tripes.
column3: Here is one going to wash the tripes.

column2: I drink no more than a sponge.
column3: I drink no more than a sponge.

column2: I drink like a Templar knight.
column3: I drink like a Templar knight.

column2: And I, tanquam sponsus.
column3: And I, tanquam sponsus.

column2: And I, sicut terra sine aqua.
column3: And I, sicut terra sine aqua.

column2: Give me a synonymon for a gammon of bacon.
column3: Give me a synonymon for a gammon of bacon.

column2: It is the compulsory of drinkers: it is a pulley.
column3: It is the compulsory of drinkers: it is a pulley.

column2: By a pulley-rope wine is let down into a cellar, and by a gammon into the stomach.
column3: By a pulley rope wine is let down into a cellar, and by a gammon into the stomach.

column2: Hey! now, boys, hither, some drink, some drink.
column3: Hey! now, boys, hither, some drink, some drink.

column2: There is no trouble in it.
column3: There is no trouble in it.

column2: Respice personam, pone pro duos, bus non est in usu.
column3: Respice personam, pone pro duos, bus non est in u s u.

column2: If I could get up as well as I can swallow down, I had been long ere now very high in the air.
column3: If I could get up as well as I can swallow down, I had been long ere now very high in the air.

column2: Thus became Tom Tosspot rich,--thus went in the tailor's stitch.
column3: Thus became Tom Tosspot rich,--thus went in the tailor's stitch.

column2: Thus did Bacchus conquer th' Inde--thus Philosophy, Melinde.
column3: Thus did Bacchus conquer t h' Inde-thus Philosophy, Melinde.

column2: A little rain allays a great deal of wind: long tippling breaks the thunder.
column3: A little rain allays a great deal of wind: long tippling breaks the thunder.

column2: But if there came such liquor from my ballock, would you not willingly thereafter suck the udder whence it issued?
column3: But if there came such liquor from my ballock, would you not willingly thereafter suck the udder whence it issued?

column2: Here, page, fill!
column3: Here, page, fill!

column2: I prithee, forget me not when it comes to my turn, and I will enter the election I have made of thee into the very register of my heart.
column3: I prithee, forget me not when it comes to my turn, and I will enter the election I have made of thee into the very register of my heart.

column2: Sup, Guillot, and spare not, there is somewhat in the pot.
column3: Sup, Guillot, and spare not, there is somewhat in the pot.

column2: I appeal from thirst, and disclaim its jurisdiction. Page, sue out my appeal in form.
column3: I appeal from thirst, and disclaim its jurisdiction. Page, sue out my appeal in form.

column2: This remnant in the bottom of the glass must follow its leader.
column3: This remnant in the bottom of the glass must follow its leader.

column2: I was wont heretofore to drink out all, but now I leave nothing.
column3: I was wont heretofore to drink out all, but now I leave nothing.

column2: Let us not make too much haste; it is requisite we carry all along with us.
column3: Let us not make too much haste; it is requisite we carry all along with us.

column2: Heyday, here are tripes fit for our sport, and, in earnest, excellent godebillios of the dun ox (you know) with the black streak.
column3: Heyday, here are tripes fit for our sport, and, in earnest, excellent godebillios of the dun ox (you know) with the black streak.

column2: O, for God's sake, let us lash them soundly, yet thriftily. Drink, or I will,--No, no, drink, I beseech you (Ou je vous, je vous prie.).
column3: O, for God's sake, let us lash them soundly, yet thriftily. Drink, or I will,--No, no, drink, I beseech you (Ou je vous, je vous prie.).

column2: Sparrows will not eat unless you bob them on the tail, nor can I drink if I be not fairly spoke to.
column3: Sparrows will not eat unless you bob them on the tail, nor can I drink if I be not fairly spoke to.

column2: The concavities of my body are like another Hell for their capacity.
column3: The concavities of my body are like another Hell for their capacity.

column2: Lagonaedatera (lagon lateris cavitas: aides orcus: and eteros alter.).
column3: Lagonaedatera (lagon lateris cavitas: aides orcus: and eteros alter.).

column2: There is not a corner, nor coney-burrow in all my body, where this wine doth not ferret out my thirst.
column3: There is not a corner, nor coney burrow in all my body, where this wine doth not ferret out my thirst.

column2: Ho, this will bang it soundly.
column3: Ho, this will bang it soundly.

column2: But this shall banish it utterly.
column3: But this shall banish it utterly.

column2: Let us wind our horns by the sound of flagons and bottles, and cry aloud, that whoever hath lost his thirst come not hither to seek it.
column3: Let us wind our horns by the sound of flagons and bottles, and cry aloud, that whoever hath lost his thirst come not hither to seek it.

column2: Long clysters of drinking are to be voided without doors.
column3: Long clysters of drinking are to be voided without doors.

column2: The great God made the planets, and we make the platters neat.
column3: The great God made the planets, and we make the platters neat.

column2: I have the word of the gospel in my mouth, Sitio.
column3: I have the word of the gospel in my mouth, Sitio.

column2: The stone called asbestos is not more unquenchable than the thirst of my paternity.
column3: The stone called asbestos is not more unquenchable than the thirst of my paternity.

column2: Appetite comes with eating, says Angeston, but the thirst goes away with drinking.
column3: Appetite comes with eating, says Angeston, but the thirst goes away with drinking.

column2: I have a remedy against thirst, quite contrary to that which is good against the biting of a mad dog.
column3: I have a remedy against thirst, quite contrary to that which is good against the biting of a mad dog.

column2: Keep running after a dog, and he will never bite you; drink always before the thirst, and it will never come upon you.
column3: Keep running after a dog, and he will never bite you; drink always before the thirst, and it will never come upon you.

column2: There I catch you, I awake you.
column3: There I catch you, I awake you.

column2: Argus had a hundred eyes for his sight, a butler should have (like Briareus) a hundred hands wherewith to fill us wine indefatigably.
column3: Argus had a hundred eyes for his sight, a butler should have (like Briareus) a hundred hands wherewith to fill us wine indefatigably.

column2: Hey now, lads, let us moisten ourselves, it will be time to dry hereafter.
column3: Hey now, lads, let us moisten ourselves, it will be time to dry hereafter.

column2: White wine here, wine, boys! Pour out all in the name of Lucifer, fill here, you, fill and fill (peascods on you) till it be full.
column3: White wine here, wine, boys! Pour out all in the name of Lucifer, fill here, you, fill and fill (peascods on you) till it be full.

column2: My tongue peels.
column3: My tongue peels.

column2: Lans trinque; to thee, countryman, I drink to thee, good fellow, comrade to thee, lusty, lively!
column3: Lans trinque; to thee, countryman, I drink to thee, good fellow, comrade to thee, lusty, lively!

column2: Ha, la, la, that was drunk to some purpose, and bravely gulped over.
column3: Ha, la, la, that was drunk to some purpose, and bravely gulped over.

column2: O lachryma Christi, it is of the best grape!
column3: O lachryma Christi, it is of the best grape!

column2: I'faith, pure Greek, Greek!
column3: I'faith, pure Greek, Greek!

column2: O the fine white wine! upon my conscience, it is a kind of taffetas wine,--hin, hin, it is of one ear, well wrought, and of good wool. Courage, comrade, up thy heart, billy!
column3: O the fine white wine! upon my conscience, it is a kind of taffetas wine,--hin, hin, it is of one ear, well wrought, and of good wool. Courage, comrade, up thy heart, billy!

column2: We will not be beasted at this bout, for I have got one trick.
column3: We will not be beasted at this bout, for I have got one trick.

column2: Ex hoc in hoc.
column3: Ex hoc in hoc.

column2: There is no enchantment nor charm there, every one of you hath seen it.
column3: There is no enchantment nor charm there, every one of you hath seen it.

column2: My 'prenticeship is out, I am a free man at this trade.
column3: My 'prenticeship is out, I am a free man at this trade.

column2: I am prester mast (Prestre mace, maistre passe.), Prish, Brum!
column3: I am prester mast (Prestre mace, maistre passe.), Prish, Brum!

column2: I should say, master past.
column3: I should say, master past.

column2: O the drinkers, those that are a-dry, O poor thirsty souls!
column3: O the drinkers, those that are a dry, O poor thirsty souls!

column2: Good page, my friend, fill me here some, and crown the wine, I pray thee.
column3: Good page, my friend, fill me here some, and crown the wine, I pray thee.

column2: Like a cardinal!
column3: Like a cardinal!

column2: Natura abhorret vacuum.
column3: Natura abhorret vacuum.

column2: Would you say that a fly could drink in this?
column3: Would you say that a fly could drink in this?

column2: This is after the fashion of Switzerland.
column3: This is after the fashion of Switzerland.

column2: Clear off, neat, supernaculum!
column3: Clear off, neat, supernaculum!

column2: Come, therefore, blades, to this divine liquor and celestial juice, swill it over heartily, and spare not!
column3: Come, therefore, blades, to this divine liquor and celestial juice, swill it over heartily, and spare not!

column2: It is a decoction of nectar and ambrosia.
column3: It is a decoction of nectar and ambrosia.
